Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Extracellular Matrix Fibrils in Stiffness Changes and Growth Factor Tethering during Fibrosis

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fibrosis is a pathological condition in which tissue healing proceeds in an uncontrolled manner. It has been estimated that nearly half of all deaths in the western world can be attributed to fibrosis. Fibrosis occurs in nearly every organ, including liver, kidney, heart, skin, and lung. While it is well appreciated that fibrosis is associated with organ failure in many disease states, there are few treatments that have proven successful. This award will support fundamental work in this area by studying the mechanobiology of fibrosis. Mechanobiology is a growing field in which researchers investigate the role of mechanical properties of cells and tissues in disease progression. The research team hypothesize that fibrosis proceeds by initially increasing the stiffness of the tissue, which then leads to the generation of larger contractile forces in local cells, which in turn drives the assembly of more stiff fibrotic tissue, resulting in uncontrolled progression of fibrosis. This research has the potential to discover important insights in fibrosis treatment by investigating the mechanical signaling that underlies fibrosis progression.

While there are tissue-specific aspects of fibrosis, there are several common themes that are seen regardless of tissue type or disease: cells at the site of fibrosis generate larger contractile forces, they secrete increased levels of extracellular matrix proteins, and they have elevated activation of the Transforming Growth Factor-beta pathway, which is implicated in many diseases, but is also critical in wound healing. Progression of fibrosis drives tissue stiffening, which ultimately disturbs tissue structure and impairs organ function. The research team hypothesizes that these common events are integrated through cell-driven assembly of the extracellular matrix protein fibronectin into elastic fibrils. These fibrils are assembled in response to cell-generated contractile forces and possess a growth-factor binding site that binds several growth factors, including Transforming Growth Factor-beta, with nanomolar affinity. The research team will investigate the hypothesis that fibronectin fibrils facilitate fibrosis by both increasing tissue stiffness in fibrotic tissue and localizing Transforming Growth Factor-beta to the cell surface via tethering to fibronectin fibrils. The team will investigate this hypothesis through the use of microfabricated pillar arrays that can quantify both cell-generated contractile forces and assembly of fibronectin fibrils. A novel tool will also be developed to quantify the stiffness of in vitro assembled extracellular matrix.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scaffolding that surrounds cells and comprises the majority of a tissue or organ is called the extracellular matrix. The extracellular matrix can affect cells in two ways: first, the stiffness or softness of the extracellular matrix affects how attached cells respond; second, the matrix can bind proteins that signal to the cells and change their response. During wound healing and fibrotic diseases, the extracellular matrix is predominantly comprised of a protein called fibronectin, which is assembled into elastic ropelike structures known as fibrils. These fibrils are assembled by “mesenchymal” cells, whose job it is to assemble new tissue. A “chicken and egg” scenario exists where cells exposed to fibronectin fibrils start turning into mesenchymal cells, which in turn causes more assembly of fibronectin fibrils, which in turn induces more cells to turn into mesenchymal cells.  The goal of this project was to investigate how fibronectin fibrils alter cellular response and to determine mechanisms to disrupt this process.


Previous studies have shown that a protein known as Transforming Growth Factor Beta, or TGF-beta, converts cells into mesenchymal cells and induces them to start assembling fibronectin fibrils. In this work, we established that fibronectin fibrils are necessary for cells to convert to a mesenchymal cell. When we blocked cells from assembling fibronectin fibrils, the cells did not convert to a mesenchymal cell. Furthermore, we showed that TGF-beta sticks to the fibronectin fibrils, and it is specifically this process that is needed to induce cells to become mesenchymal cells. When binding of TGF-beta to fibronectin fibrils was blocked, they again did not convert to mesenchymal cells. 


A second effect of TGF-beta is that it induces cells to generate larger contractile forces, which is a key part of assembly of fibronectin fibrils--the fibrils are assembled by cells stretching open fibronectin, which then starts a cascade that leads to the development of the ropelike structure. This again is a “chicken and egg” scenario: as cells start assembling fibronectin fibrils, they are able to generate larger forces, which allow them to assemble more fibronectin fibrils. In this work, we demonstrated that if we block fibronectin fibril assembly, cells are unable to generate larger forces. Since larger forces are thought to be important in cells turning into mesenchymal cells, then we provide a mechanism to stop this by blocking fibronectin fibril formation. 

Finally, one of the key missing pieces of information in fibronectin fibril signaling is that we don’t have a way to measure how stiff or soft individual fibronectin fibrils are. In this project, we developed a tool that allows us to stretch individual fibronectin fibrils, and measure the reaction force. This allows us to quantify the mechanical properties of the fibrils. Future work using this tool will allow us to determine if cells assemble fibronectin fibrils with different properties depending on cell type or disease state. These studies will be invaluable to understanding the complex relationship between cell and extracellular matrix.
